packageMeta.name: purescript-pathy
packageMeta.description: A type-safe abstraction for platform-independent file paths

declarations.comments: A type used for both directory and file names, indexed by `DirOrFile`.
declarations.title: Name
splitName

declarations.comments:
Joins name and extension part into one `Name`.

Also for any `Name` this property holds:
```purescript
joinName <<< splitName = id
````
see [`splitName`](#v:splitName).
declarations.title: joinName

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the extension of a name. also see [`splitName`](#v:splitName)

```purescript
extension (Name ".foo")    == Nothing
extension (Name "foo.")    == Nothing
extension (Name ".")       == Nothing
extension (Name "foo.baz") == Just "baz"
````
_Note, in real code all strings from this examples would be `NonEmptyString`._
declarations.title: extension

declarations.comments:
Alters an extension of a name. This allows extensions to be added, removed,
or modified. see [`splitName`](#v:splitName) and [`joinName`](#v:joinName)
for how a `Name` is split into name and extention part and joined back
into a `Name`.

Also for any `Name` this property holds:
```purescript
alterExtension id = id
````
declarations.title: alterExtension

declarations.comments: A parser for POSIX paths.
declarations.title: posixParser

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse a relative file.
declarations.title: parseRelFile

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse a relative directory.
declarations.title: parseRelDir

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse an absolute file.
declarations.title: parseAbsFile

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse an absolute directory.
declarations.title: parseAbsDir

declarations.comments: A type describing a relative file or directory path.
declarations.title: RelPath

declarations.comments:
A type describing a file whose location is given relative to some other,
unspecified directory (referred to as the "current directory").
declarations.title: RelFile

declarations.comments:
A type describing a directory whose location is given relative to some
other, unspecified directory (referred to as the "current directory").
declarations.title: RelDir

declarations.comments:
A type that describes a Path. All flavors of paths are described by this
type, whether they are absolute or relative paths and whether they
refer to files or directories.

* The type parameter `a` describes whether the path is `Rel` or `Abs`.
* The type parameter `b` describes whether the path is `File` or `Dir`.

To ensure type safety, there is no way for users to create a value of
this type directly. Instead, helpers should be used, such as `rootDir`,
`currentDir`, `file`, `dir`,  `(</>)`, and `parsePath`.

This ADT allows invalid paths (e.g. paths inside files), but there is no
possible way for such paths to be constructed by user-land code.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments: A type describing a file or directory path.
declarations.title: AnyPath

declarations.comments: A type describing a absolute or relative file path.
declarations.title: AnyFile

declarations.comments: A type describing a absolute or relative directory path.
declarations.title: AnyDir

declarations.comments: A type describing an absolute file or directory path.
declarations.title: AbsPath

declarations.comments: A type describing a file whose location is absolutely specified.
declarations.title: AbsFile

declarations.comments: A type describing a directory whose location is absolutely specified.
declarations.title: AbsDir

declarations.comments:
Sets the extension on the terminal segment of a path. If the path is
`rootDir` / `currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this
will have no effect.

```purescript
file "image" <.> "png"
```
See [`splitName`](Pathy.Name#v:splitName) and [`alterExtension`](Pathy.Name#v:alterExtension)
fore more examples.
declarations.title: setExtension

declarations.comments: The root directory, which can be used to define absolutely-located resources.
declarations.title: rootDir

declarations.comments:
Attempts to rename the terminal segment of a path using a function that
returns the result in some `Applicative`. If the path is `rootDir` /
`currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this will
have no effect.
declarations.title: renameTraverse

declarations.comments:
Attempts to rename the terminal segment of a path. If the path is
`rootDir` / `currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this
will have no effect.
declarations.title: rename

declarations.comments:
Makes a path relative to a reference path. This function is best
explaned using this property:

```purescript
a == r </> a `relativeTo` r
```
declarations.title: relativeTo

declarations.comments: Refines path segments but does not change anything else.
declarations.title: refine

declarations.comments:
Peels off the last director and terminal file from a path. Unlike the
general `peel` function this is guaranteed to return a result, as `File`
paths are known to have a name.
declarations.title: peelFile

declarations.comments:
Peels off the last directory and the terminal file or directory name
from the path. Returns `Nothing` if the path is `rootDir` / `currentDir` or
a relative path that is ascending (`../`)
declarations.title: peel

declarations.comments:
Creates a path that points to the parent directory of the specified path.

Calling `parentOf` on `rootDir` will return `rootDir`.
declarations.title: parentOf

declarations.comments:
Ascends into the parent of the specified directory, then descends into
the specified path.

```purescript
rootDir </> dir "foo" <..> dir "bar" = rootDir </> dir "bar"
```
declarations.title: parentAppend

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the name of the terminal segment in a path. Returns `Nothing` if
the path is `rootDir` / `currentDir` or some `parentOf p`.
declarations.title: name

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative directory or file of the specified name.
In most cases [`dir'`](#v:dir') or [`file'`](#v:file') should be used instead,
but it's still there in case the segment type is going to be determined based
on some type variable.

``` purescript
p == maybe p (\(Tuple r n) -> r </> in' n) (peel p)
```
declarations.title: in'

declarations.comments:
A fold over `Path`s. Since `Path` has private constructors, this allows for
functions to be written over its constructors, similar to a total pattern
match.

- The first argument is the value to return for the `currentDir`/`rootDir`
  at the base of the path.
- The second argument is a function for handling a step into the parent
  directory of the path it receives (eliminates `parentOf`).
- The third argument is a function representing a file or directory within
  the directory of the path it receives (eliminates `extendPath`).
declarations.title: foldPath

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the name of a file path. Unlike the general `name` function,
this is guaranteed to return a result, as `File` paths are known to have a
name.
declarations.title: fileName

declarations.comments: Creates a path which points to a relative file of the specified name.
declarations.title: file'

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative file of the specified name.

Instead of accepting a runtime value, this function accepts a type-level
string via a proxy, to ensure the constructed name is not empty.
declarations.title: file

declarations.comments: Extends a path with a file or directory under the current path.
declarations.title: extendPath

declarations.comments: Creates a path which points to a relative directory of the specified name.
declarations.title: dir'

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative directory of the specified name.

Instead of accepting a runtime value, this function accepts a type-level
string via a proxy, to ensure the constructed name is not empty.
declarations.title: dir

declarations.comments:
The "current directory", which can be used to define relatively-located
resources.
declarations.title: currentDir

declarations.comments:
Given a directory path, appends a relative path to extend the original
path.
declarations.title: appendPath

declarations.comments: The phantom type of relative paths.
declarations.title: Rel

declarations.comments: The phantom type of files.
declarations.title: File

declarations.comments: The phantom type of directories.
declarations.title: Dir

declarations.comments: The phantom type of absolute paths.
declarations.title: Abs

declarations.comments:
A class that enables writing operations that abstract over `DirOrFile`.

The provided `onDirOrFile` function folds over a value indexed by
`DirOrFile` to produce a new result, passing proof/coercion functions to
allow the inner functions to unify their return types if remapping.
declarations.title: IsDirOrFile

declarations.comments:
A class that enables writing operations that abstract over `RelOrAbs`.

The provided `onRelOrAbs` function folds over a value indexed by
`RelOrAbs` to produce a new result, passing proof/coercion functions to
allow the inner functions to unify their return types if remapping.
declarations.title: IsRelOrAbs

declarations.comments: Folds over a value that uses `RelOrAbs` to produce a new result.
declarations.title: foldRelOrAbs

declarations.comments: Folds over a value that uses `DirOrFile` to produce a new result.
declarations.title: foldDirOrFile

declarations.comments:
A `Printer` defines options for printing paths.

- `root` is a function used to construct the initial segment of paths.
- `current` is a representation of the current directory.
- `up` is a representation of going up to the parent directory.
- `sep` is the string to separate path segments by.
- `escaper` specified how to deal with printing reserved names and
   characters.
declarations.title: Printer

declarations.comments:
An `Escaper` encodes segments or characters which have reserved meaning
within names in a path.
declarations.title: Escaper

declarations.comments: A printer for Windows paths.
declarations.title: windowsPrinter

declarations.comments:
Prints a `SandboxedPath` into its canonical `String` representation, using
the specified printer. This will print a relative path if `b ~ Rel`, which
depending on how the resulting string is used, may be unsafe.
declarations.title: unsafePrintPath

declarations.comments:
Prints a `SandboxedPath` into its canonical `String` representation, using
the specified printer. The printed path will always be absolute, as this
is the only way to ensure the path is safely referring to the intended
location.
declarations.title: printPath

declarations.comments: A printer for POSIX paths.
declarations.title: posixPrinter

declarations.comments:
Prints a path exactly according to its representation. This should only be
used for debug purposes. Using this function will raise a warning at
compile time as a reminder!
declarations.title: debugPrintPath

declarations.comments: The type for paths that have been sandboxed.
declarations.title: SandboxedPath

declarations.comments: Extracts the original path from a `SandboxedPath`.
declarations.title: unsandbox

declarations.comments: Returns the location a `SandboxedPath` was sandboxed to.
declarations.title: sandboxRoot

declarations.comments:
Sandboxes any path to `/`.

This should only be used for situations where a path is already constrained
within a system so that access to `/` is safe - for instance, in URIs.
declarations.title: sandboxAny

declarations.comments:
Attempts to sandbox a path relative to an absolute directory ("sandbox
root"). If the `Path a b` escapes the sandbox root `Nothing` will be
returned.
declarations.title: sandbox

declarations.comments: A type used for both directory and file names, indexed by `DirOrFile`.
declarations.title: Name
splitName

declarations.comments:
Joins name and extension part into one `Name`.

Also for any `Name` this property holds:
```purescript
joinName <<< splitName = id
````
see [`splitName`](#v:splitName).
declarations.title: joinName

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the extension of a name. also see [`splitName`](#v:splitName)

```purescript
extension (Name ".foo")    == Nothing
extension (Name "foo.")    == Nothing
extension (Name ".")       == Nothing
extension (Name "foo.baz") == Just "baz"
````
_Note, in real code all strings from this examples would be `NonEmptyString`._
declarations.title: extension

declarations.comments:
Alters an extension of a name. This allows extensions to be added, removed,
or modified. see [`splitName`](#v:splitName) and [`joinName`](#v:joinName)
for how a `Name` is split into name and extention part and joined back
into a `Name`.

Also for any `Name` this property holds:
```purescript
alterExtension id = id
````
declarations.title: alterExtension

declarations.comments:
A class for creating `Name` values from type-level strings. This allows us
to guarantee that a name is not empty at compile-time.
declarations.title: IsName

declarations.comments: A parser for POSIX paths.
declarations.title: posixParser

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse a relative file.
declarations.title: parseRelFile

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse an absolute file.
declarations.title: parseAbsFile

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse a relative directory.
declarations.title: parseRelDir

declarations.comments: Attempts to parse an absolute directory.
declarations.title: parseAbsDir

declarations.comments:
A type that describes a Path. All flavors of paths are described by this
type, whether they are absolute or relative paths and whether they
refer to files or directories.

* The type parameter `a` describes whether the path is `Rel` or `Abs`.
* The type parameter `b` describes whether the path is `File` or `Dir`.

To ensure type safety, there is no way for users to create a value of
this type directly. Instead, helpers should be used, such as `rootDir`,
`currentDir`, `file`, `dir`,  `(</>)`, and `parsePath`.

This ADT allows invalid paths (e.g. paths inside files), but there is no
possible way for such paths to be constructed by user-land code.
declarations.title: Path

declarations.comments: A type describing a file or directory path.
declarations.title: AnyPath

declarations.comments: A type describing a relative file or directory path.
declarations.title: RelPath

declarations.comments: A type describing an absolute file or directory path.
declarations.title: AbsPath

declarations.comments:
A type describing a directory whose location is given relative to some
other, unspecified directory (referred to as the "current directory").
declarations.title: RelDir

declarations.comments: A type describing a directory whose location is absolutely specified.
declarations.title: AbsDir

declarations.comments: A type describing a absolute or relative directory path.
declarations.title: AnyDir

declarations.comments:
A type describing a file whose location is given relative to some other,
unspecified directory (referred to as the "current directory").
declarations.title: RelFile

declarations.comments: A type describing a file whose location is absolutely specified.
declarations.title: AbsFile

declarations.comments: A type describing a absolute or relative file path.
declarations.title: AnyFile

declarations.comments: The root directory, which can be used to define absolutely-located resources.
declarations.title: rootDir

declarations.comments:
The "current directory", which can be used to define relatively-located
resources.
declarations.title: currentDir

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative directory of the specified name.

Instead of accepting a runtime value, this function accepts a type-level
string via a proxy, to ensure the constructed name is not empty.
declarations.title: dir

declarations.comments: Creates a path which points to a relative directory of the specified name.
declarations.title: dir'

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative file of the specified name.

Instead of accepting a runtime value, this function accepts a type-level
string via a proxy, to ensure the constructed name is not empty.
declarations.title: file

declarations.comments: Creates a path which points to a relative file of the specified name.
declarations.title: file'

declarations.comments:
Creates a path which points to a relative directory or file of the specified name.
In most cases [`dir'`](#v:dir') or [`file'`](#v:file') should be used instead,
but it's still there in case the segment type is going to be determined based
on some type variable.

``` purescript
p == maybe p (\(Tuple r n) -> r </> in' n) (peel p)
```
declarations.title: in'

declarations.comments:
Creates a path that points to the parent directory of the specified path.

Calling `parentOf` on `rootDir` will return `rootDir`.
declarations.title: parentOf

declarations.comments: Extends a path with a file or directory under the current path.
declarations.title: extendPath

declarations.comments:
Given a directory path, appends a relative path to extend the original
path.
declarations.title: appendPath

declarations.comments:
Ascends into the parent of the specified directory, then descends into
the specified path.

```purescript
rootDir </> dir "foo" <..> dir "bar" = rootDir </> dir "bar"
```
declarations.title: parentAppend

declarations.comments:
A fold over `Path`s. Since `Path` has private constructors, this allows for
functions to be written over its constructors, similar to a total pattern
match.

- The first argument is the value to return for the `currentDir`/`rootDir`
  at the base of the path.
- The second argument is a function for handling a step into the parent
  directory of the path it receives (eliminates `parentOf`).
- The third argument is a function representing a file or directory within
  the directory of the path it receives (eliminates `extendPath`).
declarations.title: foldPath

declarations.comments:
Peels off the last directory and the terminal file or directory name
from the path. Returns `Nothing` if the path is `rootDir` / `currentDir` or
a relative path that is ascending (`../`)
declarations.title: peel

declarations.comments:
Peels off the last director and terminal file from a path. Unlike the
general `peel` function this is guaranteed to return a result, as `File`
paths are known to have a name.
declarations.title: peelFile

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the name of the terminal segment in a path. Returns `Nothing` if
the path is `rootDir` / `currentDir` or some `parentOf p`.
declarations.title: name

declarations.comments:
Retrieves the name of a file path. Unlike the general `name` function,
this is guaranteed to return a result, as `File` paths are known to have a
name.
declarations.title: fileName

declarations.comments:
Attempts to rename the terminal segment of a path. If the path is
`rootDir` / `currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this
will have no effect.
declarations.title: rename

declarations.comments:
Attempts to rename the terminal segment of a path using a function that
returns the result in some `Applicative`. If the path is `rootDir` /
`currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this will
have no effect.
declarations.title: renameTraverse

declarations.comments:
Sets the extension on the terminal segment of a path. If the path is
`rootDir` / `currentDir` or a relative path that is ascending (`../`) this
will have no effect.

```purescript
file "image" <.> "png"
```
See [`splitName`](Pathy.Name#v:splitName) and [`alterExtension`](Pathy.Name#v:alterExtension)
fore more examples.
declarations.title: setExtension

declarations.comments:
Makes a path relative to a reference path. This function is best
explaned using this property:

```purescript
a == r </> a `relativeTo` r
```
declarations.title: relativeTo

declarations.comments: Refines path segments but does not change anything else.
declarations.title: refine

declarations.comments: The kind for the relative/absolute phantom type.
declarations.title: RelOrAbs

declarations.comments: The phantom type of relative paths.
declarations.title: Rel

declarations.comments: The phantom type of absolute paths.
declarations.title: Abs

declarations.comments:
A class that enables writing operations that abstract over `RelOrAbs`.

The provided `onRelOrAbs` function folds over a value indexed by
`RelOrAbs` to produce a new result, passing proof/coercion functions to
allow the inner functions to unify their return types if remapping.
declarations.title: IsRelOrAbs

declarations.comments: Folds over a value that uses `RelOrAbs` to produce a new result.
declarations.title: foldRelOrAbs

declarations.comments: The kind for the directory/file phantom type.
declarations.title: DirOrFile

declarations.comments: The phantom type of directories.
declarations.title: Dir

declarations.comments: The phantom type of files.
declarations.title: File

declarations.comments:
A class that enables writing operations that abstract over `DirOrFile`.

The provided `onDirOrFile` function folds over a value indexed by
`DirOrFile` to produce a new result, passing proof/coercion functions to
allow the inner functions to unify their return types if remapping.
declarations.title: IsDirOrFile

declarations.comments: Folds over a value that uses `DirOrFile` to produce a new result.
declarations.title: foldDirOrFile

declarations.comments:
A `Printer` defines options for printing paths.

- `root` is a function used to construct the initial segment of paths.
- `current` is a representation of the current directory.
- `up` is a representation of going up to the parent directory.
- `sep` is the string to separate path segments by.
- `escaper` specified how to deal with printing reserved names and
   characters.
declarations.title: Printer

declarations.comments: A printer for POSIX paths.
declarations.title: posixPrinter

declarations.comments: A printer for Windows paths.
declarations.title: windowsPrinter

declarations.comments:
Prints a `SandboxedPath` into its canonical `String` representation, using
the specified printer. The printed path will always be absolute, as this
is the only way to ensure the path is safely referring to the intended
location.
declarations.title: printPath

declarations.comments:
Prints a `SandboxedPath` into its canonical `String` representation, using
the specified printer. This will print a relative path if `b ~ Rel`, which
depending on how the resulting string is used, may be unsafe.
declarations.title: unsafePrintPath

declarations.comments:
Prints a path exactly according to its representation. This should only be
used for debug purposes. Using this function will raise a warning at
compile time as a reminder!
declarations.title: debugPrintPath

declarations.comments:
An `Escaper` encodes segments or characters which have reserved meaning
within names in a path.
declarations.title: Escaper

declarations.comments: An escaper that replaces all `'/'` characters in a name with `'-'`s.
declarations.title: slashEscaper

declarations.comments:
An escaper that replaces names `"."` and `".."` with `"$dot"` and
`"$dot$dot"`.
declarations.title: dotEscaper

declarations.comments:
An escaper that removes all slashes, converts ".." into "$dot$dot", and
converts "." into "$dot".
declarations.title: posixEscaper

declarations.comments:
An escaper that attempts to encode all reserved names and characters for
windows-style paths.
declarations.title: windowsEscaper

declarations.comments: Prints a name as a `String` using the specified escaper.
declarations.title: escape

declarations.comments: The type for paths that have been sandboxed.
declarations.title: SandboxedPath

declarations.comments:
Attempts to sandbox a path relative to an absolute directory ("sandbox
root"). If the `Path a b` escapes the sandbox root `Nothing` will be
returned.
declarations.title: sandbox

declarations.comments:
Sandboxes any path to `/`.

This should only be used for situations where a path is already constrained
within a system so that access to `/` is safe - for instance, in URIs.
declarations.title: sandboxAny

declarations.comments: Returns the location a `SandboxedPath` was sandboxed to.
declarations.title: sandboxRoot

declarations.comments: Extracts the original path from a `SandboxedPath`.
declarations.title: unsandbox
